text: I’m not going to hazard a guess about numbers but you and Andrew Adonis really need to talk

text: For much of the day my feed featured remainers complaining that the bbc were only reporting ‘tens of thousands’ for several hours. Which it was, because I had the news channel on.

author: JenWilliamsMEN

text: Just got a taxi in Aberystwyth and asked the driver about last weekend after the rugby. ‘It was great,’ he said. ‘There were people passed out on the pavement from 6pm and by 11pm town was empty.’ That’s what I like to hear.
author: JenWilliamsMEN

text: Never let it be said my generation weren’t engaged with politics before brexit.
author: JenWilliamsMEN

text: Had to be bundled into a cab complaining ‘but WHY won’t they do burgers? Bush is such a c***’
author: JenWilliamsMEN

text: Today brings back memories of the Iraq protests and the mate who finished a bar shift, got drunk and was so outraged that McDonald’s was only doing breakfasts that he wrote ‘no to Bush, yes to Burger Time’ on a bit of A4 and marched up and down the Portland St branch chanting
author: JenWilliamsMEN

text:
Spending my day re-exploring Aberystwyth. This has involved reading about the castle. My key takeaway: the Welsh built it, burned it down, rebuilt it, burned it down. 
The English rebuilt it, the Welsh burned it down, rebuilt it. The English retook it. Then it fell down. Love it.
author: JenWilliamsMEN

text: this, a thousand times
author: JenWilliamsMEN

text: Yeah, no time for that nonsense
author: JenWilliamsMEN

text:
Staying in a posh hotel with a mate, who has cleared the cheese singlehandedly. Went to go for the last bit and he went ‘no, not that one’.

It’s butter. And he’d ate half of it before figuring it out. 

#mancsontour
author: JenWilliamsMEN

text: The brexit secretary abstaining on his own proposal
author: JenWilliamsMEN

text: Not the worst Brexit plan I’ve heard mind
author: JenWilliamsMEN

text:
Uri Geller has written to the PM. Enough is enough, it turns out. 

‘I love you very much but will not allow you to lead Britain into brexit. I will stop you telepathically from doing this.’
author: JenWilliamsMEN

text: /terrifying obviously
author: JenWilliamsMEN

text:
‘Asked three times what she would do if she lost the vote, she couldn’t say. It was f*cking awful. Dreadful. Evasive even by her standards.’
Weirdly reassuring that even the entire EU can’t get T May to answer the most basics qs
author: JenWilliamsMEN

text: T May to parliament: whoops sorry guys I didn’t mean it
author: JenWilliamsMEN

text: No, it came from parliamentary gossip but I’ve been doing my own thing today so wasn’t sure if everyone else had heard it too. Looks like they haven’t. (Which means it could be bollocks- it has a heavy gossip bracket around it.)
author: JenWilliamsMEN

text: Anyway obviously all that might be bollocks. I reserve the right, as a political journalist, to tell you stuff that will be disproved within literally 30 seconds
author: JenWilliamsMEN

text: Someone whose primary goal is to personally protect the PM, rather than tactically or strategically do something that makes any political sense, might do that. Anyone who works for her and advised that obviously wants sacking
author: JenWilliamsMEN

text: I’ve paid little attention to the gossip and detail round politics in the last 24 hours or so, so if this is already out there then ignore me. But according to one MP, the T May speech last night was designed and orchestrated by P May. Suddenly, it makes sense.
author: JenWilliamsMEN

text: Loving the translator from the Juncker press conference. He sounds like he wants to end absolutely everything, all of it, life itself
author: JenWilliamsMEN

text: Yesssss
author: JenWilliamsMEN

text: Not sure what chess strategy Theresa May is playing because I'm rubbish at chess, but I've got a rough idea of humans. And even as self-anointed president, she still needs the support of her MPs, most of whom she's now massively pissed off as humans.
author: JenWilliamsMEN

text: The thing is, this time I didn't cancel anything, I just bought a bottle of wine and carried on writing my feature but kept the telly on. You might trick me once,  T May, but you won't trick me twice

text: I see the new government line is ‘the public wants it over’. Yes, but you can’t then make that argument to do literally whatever you want. ‘The public wants this over so I’ve bought this box of matches and some petrol, back in a minute.’
author: JenWilliamsMEN

text: I just long for a different type of chaos, anything but this
author: JenWilliamsMEN

text: Ok I never thought I’d say this but please bring me the blessed relief of a general election
author: JenWilliamsMEN

text: ‘Some people’ think a lot of things, including below the line and on edl marches. That doesn’t mean they represent a city.
author: JenWilliamsMEN

text: My tweet wasn’t attempting to save the world. But I know how my gay friends feel about this so I don’t think it’s unhelpful for me to say no, this is not what this city represents imo. And it worries me how much is being allowed to slide because ‘some people think this’.
author: JenWilliamsMEN

text: By standing up and saying no. How far do you need things to go? If a group of ppl here said ‘women need to shut up and stay at home’, would you say: ‘well that’s Manchester, because some people in Manchester think women should shut up and stay at home’?
author: JenWilliamsMEN

text: Actually, no. It’s been bottled up because the majority of people simply, rightly, wouldn’t accept it. Manchester has a history of not accepting it and remains that city from where I’m sitting.
author: JenWilliamsMEN

text: In the same way people stood at the side with angry placards during Pride aren’t Manchester; the people in the parade are.
author: JenWilliamsMEN

text: This isn’t Manchester.
author: JenWilliamsMEN
